abstracts.cdata!:
The global objective of the project is
            to improve the efficiency of the Niger financial system so
            that it can fulfill its important role of contributing to
            growth and poverty reduction. The project has the following
            six components: Component 1) a favorable environment within
            which financial institutions operate is a necessary
            condition for a successful restructuring of the financial
            sector. Two areas have been identified as retarding factors
            in the development of financial institutions: Government
            arrears and the legal/judiciary framework. In addition, the
            lack of financing of small and medium-sized enterprises
            (SMEs) remains a concern and an issue is how to make the
            environment more conducive to SME financing. Component 2) of
            the four banks identified as problematic, the restructuring
            of two of them, Banque Commerciale du Niger (BCN), and
            Banque Islamique du Niger pour le Commerce et
            l'Investissement (BINCI), is close to completion. The
            project will monitor progress with the restructuring of
            these two banks, but it will mainly focus on Credit du Niver
            (CDN) and Caisse de Pret aux Collectivites Territoriales
            (CPCT). Component 3) Micro-finance institutions and the
            postal financial services bring financial intermediation to
            the neighborhoods in towns and cities and to rural areas.
            Component 4) Social security affords much needed protection
            to the workers (against work related accidents and
            illnesses), to the young (through family allowances) and to
            the old (through the pension system). The Caisse Nationale
            de Securite Sociale (CNSS) which provides coverage to
            salaried workers is bankrupt and suffers from a liquidity
            shortage; its reach is very limited, less than 10 percent of
            the population, and it does not offer some products (such as
            health care). The imbalance between benefits paid and
            contributions collected increases each year and constitutes
            a serious public finance risk. Component 5) All studies of
            the financial system of Niger have underscored the capacity
            deficiencies at all levels. The project will contribute to
            fund capacity building in commercial banks, insurance
            companies, micro-finance institutions, the postal bank, as
            well as within the Ministry of Finance to reinforce the
            department of money and credit and the division of
            insurance. Component 6) The Credit will fund the costs of
            project management, including four staff, and equipment.
